--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> Things were going very slowly.  The original seed topology (no 
hidden nodes) 
> was still alive and kicking, and battling it out for first place 
in the 
> population, which means that things weren't exactly progressing...
> 

Last time I looked at your fitness graph it was going up; why do you 
feel things weren't improving?  As long as things are improving 
there's nothing wrong with the simplest topology persisting.  
Actually that's what you'd hope to happen because it means that the 
current level of fitness can be achieved with a very small network, 
and you want to keep things small for as long as possible.

ken

> So I decided to speed things up.  I chopped down the number of 
networks in 
> the population so that packets get returned sooner.  Found a bug 
in my 
> offspring allocation code in the process...oops...but that's fixed 
now.
> 
> So now I'm trying to get through the generations faster in an 
attempt to 
> make some progress.  Problem is, I think I may have done myself a 
> disservice.  By having the evaluation code start at the reduction 
side and 
> work its way up to enlargement, it seems the pressure is to create 
a network 
> that merely averages its pixel inputs.  And I'm not convinced that 
it will 
> be able to (easily) break away from that pressure, even as 
topology is 
> added.  It might, but I'm thinking that I would be better off if I 
just went 
> ahead and calculated all activations rather than trying to short-
circuit the 
> calculations for less fit networks.  What do you guys think?
> 
> -- John
